Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CI build throws error NU5104 and succeeds regardless" (#9930) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Details about Problem

Our CI build produces multiple instances of warning NU5104 (treated as error)
However, the CI build succeeds.

This may lead engineer diagnosing a build failure on an incorrect path, wasting their time, because the error which caused the build failure is buried somewhere else in the log.

The expected behavior is either
1. Make these warnings and allow the build to succeed
2. Fail the build since it has errors

The incorrect behavior is to see this in the logs
`15 Error(s) \ Successfully built`

## Versions

I'm not sure which nuget version it's used. It's happening in CI within DevDiv
```
Agent name: 'vs2019mb-00000J'
Agent machine name: 'vs2019mb-00000J'
Current agent version: '2.171.1'
Agent running as: 'dlab14'
```

The error originates at `dotnet\sdk\3.0.101\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(198,5)`

NuGet product used:
msbuild using .NET SDK 3.0.101 in AzureDevOps CI build

NuGet version:
NuGet 5.0.2 x64

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): n/a

VS version (if appropriate): n/a

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): n/a

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1.  Pick any passing build in this definition: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build?definitionId=8282
For a recent example, take https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3999127&view=logs&j=2d2b3007-3c5c-5840-9bb0-2b1ea49925f3&t=08e986c2-058e-5f01-51da-ae4278e2d74e

2. Go to the build log

3. Observe
```
C:\A\1\_tool\dotnet\sdk\3.0.100\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(198,5): error NU5104: A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. Either modify the version spec of dependency "Microsoft.Internal.VisualStudio.Shell.Embeddable [16.6.29918.18-pre, )" or update the version field in the nuspec. [C:\A\1\13\s\src\Editor\VisualStudio\Impl\EditorImpl.csproj]
C:\A\1\_tool\dotnet\sdk\3.0.100\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(198,5): error NU5104: A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. Either modify the version spec of dependency "Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading [16.7.29-alpha, )" or update the version field in the nuspec. [C:\A\1\13\s\src\Editor\Text\Test\Util\TextUnitTestHelper\TextUnitTestHelper.csproj]
C:\A\1\_tool\dotnet\sdk\3.0.100\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(198,5): error NU5104: A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. Either modify the version spec of dependency "Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading [16.7.29-alpha, )" or update the version field in the nuspec. [C:\A\1\13\s\src\Editor\Text\Test\Util\EditorTestApp\EditorTestApp.csproj]
C:\A\1\_tool\dotnet\sdk\3.0.100\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(198,5): error NU5104: A stable release of a package should not have a prerelease dependency. Either modify the version spec of dependency "Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading [16.7.29-alpha, )" or update the version field in the nuspec. [C:\A\1\13\s\src\Editor\Text\Test\Util\TextViewUnitTestHelper\TextViewUnitTestHelper.csproj]
    1505 Warning(s)
    15 Error(s)

Time Elapsed 01:10:07.28
Successfully built
```
Specifically, the issue is seeing these two messages:
`15 Error(s) \ Successfully built`

Please let us know whether this is an AzureDevOps configuration issue
Thanks!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "MSBuild project evaluation fails when TargetFramework property includes semicolon" (#9927) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The .NET SDK is now using `NuGetFramework` methods to parse the `TargetFramework` property, via MSBuild intrinsic functions that were added for this:

https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/blob/5b50ac24ecd5af91736cf81360eab5813c9e93b9/src/Tasks/Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks/targets/Microsoft.NET.TargetFrameworkInference.targets#L54-L55

However, this is causing MSBuild evaluation to fail with an assertion when the `TargetFramework` property has a semicolon in it (for example `netcoreapp2.0;net461`).  What is supposed to happen is for the SDK to generate an error during the build:

> error NETSDK1046: The TargetFramework value 'netcoreapp2.0;net461' is not valid. To multi-target, use the 'TargetFrameworks' property instead.

However, instead evaluation fails with the following:

> ---- DEBUG ASSERTION FAILED ----
---- Assert Short Message ----
invalid folder name, this appears to contain multiple frameworks
---- Assert Long Message ----
>
>   at NuGet.Frameworks.NuGetFramework.Parse(String folderName, IFrameworkNameProvider mappings)
   at NuGet.Frameworks.NuGetFramework.Parse(String folderName)
   at System.RuntimeMethodHandle.InvokeMethod(Object target, Object[] arguments, Signature sig, Boolean constructor, Boolean wrapExceptions)
   at System.Reflection.RuntimeMethodInfo.Invoke(Object obj, BindingFlags invokeAttr, Binder binder, Object[] parameters, CultureInfo culture)
   at System.Reflection.MethodBase.Invoke(Object obj, Object[] parameters)
   at Microsoft.Build.Evaluation.NuGetFrameworkWrapper.Parse(String tfm) in C:\git\msbuild\src\Build\Utilities\NuGetFrameworkWrapper.cs:line 55
   at Microsoft.Build.Evaluation.NuGetFrameworkWrapper.GetTargetFrameworkIdentifier(String tfm) in C:\git\msbuild\src\Build\Utilities\NuGetFrameworkWrapper.cs:line 60
   at Microsoft.Build.Evaluation.IntrinsicFunctions.GetTargetFrameworkIdentifier(String tfm) in C:\git\msbuild\src\Build\Evaluation\IntrinsicFunctions.cs:line 486

I think to fix this the parse methods should return "Unsupported" instead of asserting when there is a semicolon in the value passed in.

I ran into this when testing private NuGet packages based on this PR: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3578.  As our tests didn't fail previously, this may have been a regression in that PR.

@nkolev92

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Analyze the frequency of OnBuild restore & potential improvements" (#9566) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is an investigative task to track one of the 3 scenarios in which restore happens. 

Questions that need answered:
* How frequent is this in the overall picture?
* What is the status distribution?
* Can it be made faster? 
* Can it happen less frequently?

Related to https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9513. 

Given that this will happen after https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9513 is completed. It's relevant to think of this problem in the context of those no-op optimizations existing.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
